summary: This is a transcript of a court proceeding, likely a pre-trial hearing or motion hearing in the case against Ghislaine Maxwell. The judge rules on government motions regarding the use of the term 'victim' and the use of pseudonyms for eight witnesses and alleged victims. The judge grants the government's request to use pseudonyms to protect witness privacy and prevent harassment, while ensuring the defendant's right to cross-examination is not unduly limited.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The defendant in the criminal case. The judge references her and the defense's arguments against using pseudonyms for witnesses.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Referenced by the judge as the central figure in the allegations of sexual abuse, with whom the witnesses' and alleged victims' experiences are connected.

persons.name: Furman
persons.context: A judge (likely Jesse M. Furman) in a related case (United States v. Dupigny) whose decision is cited by the presiding judge in this transcript.

connections.description: Maxwell is on trial for allegations related to facilitating Epstein's sexual abuse of minors. The judge notes witnesses will testify about 'illegal sexual abuse' concerning Epstein.
Judge Furman's prior ruling in a different case is cited as legal precedent by the judge presiding over Maxwell's case.

events.title: Hearing in United States v. Dupigny
events.description: A hearing in a related case (Docket No. 198) where Judge Furman ruled on the use of the term 'victim', a decision cited as precedent.

events.title: Upcoming Trial of Ghislaine Maxwell
events.description: The subject of the hearing. The judge is making pre-trial rulings on motions regarding witness pseudonyms and the use of the term 'victim' in this highly publicized case.

keyFacts: The judge grants the government's motion to allow eight individuals (witnesses and alleged victims) to be referred to by pseudonyms or first names during the trial to protect their privacy and prevent harassment.

The judge rules that the government may use the term 'victim' during trial, finding it is not inherently prejudicial and any potential prejudice can be cured by jury instructions on the presumption of innocence.
The defense is already aware of the true identities of all eight individuals, and the jury will also be made aware; the pseudonyms are only for use in open court.
The judge orders the parties to submit a joint proposal by November 10 for the pseudonyms to be used and for a limiting instruction to the jury explaining the reason for the privacy precautions.

The judge emphasizes that the defense's right to cross-examine witnesses will not be unduly limited, though specific identifying information (like employer names, family member names, addresses) should not be elicited.
